children.value: In high-school, we learned about the

children.html: …y=2x+1\displaystyle \quad \dots \quad y = 2x+1…y=2x+1
…2x−y+1=0\displaystyle \quad \dots \quad 2x-y+1 = 0…2x−y+1=0

children.value: The difference between these two forms is that in explicit form we know the formula by which

children.html: yyy

children.value: is given, while in implicit form we don’t immediately know that formula (although we can easily compute it). This same method can be used for more general functions.

children.html: y(x)=ex+3.y(x) = e^x+3.y(x)=ex+3.

children.value: because we are given the formula by which

children.html: yyy

children.value: is defined. However, we can preform the following operations:

children.html: y=ex+3ex=y−3/ln⁡x=ln⁡(y−3)\begin{split} y &= e^x+3 \\ e^x &= y-3 \quad / \ln \\ x &= \ln(y-3) \end{split}yexx​=ex+3=y−3/ln=ln(y−3)​
x−ln⁡(y−3)=0.x-\ln(y-3) = 0.x−ln(y−3)=0.
yyy

children.value: because we don’t immediately know the formula by which the function

children.html: yyy

children.value: is defined, but we can easily express

children.html: yyy

children.value: from that equation and find the explicit form.
Sometimes, the implict form of a function can be such that we can’t explicitly express

children.html: yyy

children.value: from the given equation. Nonetheless, we know how to compute the derivative of implicitly given function, as the following problems show.

y′y'y′
yyy

y(0)=2,y(0) = 2,y(0)=2,
y′(2).y'(2).y′(2).

y′(1).y'(1).y′(1).

children.value: So far, we have learned how to find the derivatives of products, quotients, compositions and implicitly given functions. However, there are still some functions that we don’t (yet) know how to differentiate. In this section, we will learn a new method that we’ll be able to use to differentiate some functions that we didn’t know how to differentiate before.
Find the derivative of the function

children.html: f(x)=xx+1.\displaystyle f(x) = x^{x+1}.f(x)=xx+1.

children.value: Find the derivative of the function

children.html: f(x)=(x2−6x+3)x+7.\displaystyle f(x) = (x^2-6x+3)^{\sqrt{x+7}}.f(x)=(x2−6x+3)x+7​.
f(x)=(x−5)ex22.\displaystyle f(x) = (x-5)^\frac{e^{x^2}}{2}.f(x)=(x−5)2ex2​.
f′(6).f'(6).f′(6).

children.value: Remember that the derivative of the function

children.html: fff
f′(x)=lim⁡h→0f(x+h)−f(x)h.f'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x+h)-f(x)}{h}.f′(x)=h→0lim​hf(x+h)−f(x)​.
hhh

children.label: approx
children.html: f(x+h)−f(x)≈f′(x)⋅h.f(x+h)-f(x) \approx f'(x) \cdot h.f(x+h)−f(x)≈f′(x)⋅h.

children.value: This approximation is very important to us, so we want to give special names to the quantities above:

children.html: …dx=h\dots dx = h…dx=h
…Δf(x0)=f(x0+dx)−f(x0)\dots \Delta f(x_0) = f(x_0 + dx)-f(x_0)…Δf(x0​)=f(x0​+dx)−f(x0​)
…df(x0)=f′(x0)⋅dx.\dots df(x_0) = f'(x_0) \cdot dx.…df(x0​)=f′(x0​)⋅dx.

children.label: differential
children.html: Δf(x0)≈df(x0).\Delta f(x_0) \approx df(x_0).Δf(x0​)≈df(x0​).

children.value: the exact change in the value of the function can be approximated by the differential.
Of course, the approximation can be accurate or not, so we need a way of measuring the error we make when using the differential to approximate the exact change:

children.html: …∣Δf(x0)−df(x0)∣ \displaystyle \dots \lvert \Delta f(x_0) - df(x_0)\rvert…∣Δf(x0​)−df(x0​)∣
…∣Δf(x0)−df(x0)∣Δf(x0)⋅100%\displaystyle \dots \frac{\lvert \Delta f(x_0) - df(x_0)\rvert}{\Delta f(x_0)} \cdot 100\%…Δf(x0​)∣Δf(x0​)−df(x0​)∣​⋅100%

R(A0)≈1158.81,R(A_0) \approx 1158.81,R(A0​)≈1158.81,

children.html: ln⁡(A)⋅A+5=1193.57\ln(A) \cdot \sqrt{A + 5} = 1193.57ln(A)⋅A+5​=1193.57

children.value: This equation is very complicated and we don’t know how to solve it using any methods that we know of. Therefore, we need to approach this problem in some other way.
the differential approximates the exact change

children.html: ΔR(A0)≈R′(A0)⋅dA,\Delta R(A_0) \approx R'(A_0) \cdot dA,ΔR(A0​)≈R′(A0​)⋅dA,
A0=14600A_0 = 14600A0​=14600

ΔR(A0)=0.03R(A0).\Delta R(A_0) = 0.03R(A_0).ΔR(A0​)=0.03R(A0​).

children.value: So, from the approximation above, the additional amount of money that needs to be invested in advertising is

children.html: dA≈ΔR(A0)R′(A0)=0.03R(A0)R′(A0)=725.02dA \approx \frac{\Delta R(A_0)}{R'(A_0)} = \frac{0.03R(A_0)}{R'(A_0)} = 725.02dA≈R′(A0​)ΔR(A0​)​=R′(A0​)0.03R(A0​)​=725.02

children.value: Therefore, the bussiness needs to invest around
euros more in advertising in order to achieve their goal.
If we would like to check whether or not our approximation was good, we can compute the revenue if the bussines invests

R(15325,02)=1193.23.R(15325,02) = 1193.23.R(15325,02)=1193.23.
3%3\%3%

Lucija, a financial analyst at a certain hedge fund, was given a task to model the value

children.value: . Based on the available data, Lucija has modelled the relationship between

P=P(r)P = P(r)P=P(r)

PPP

children.value: is given implicitly, we use implicit differentiation to compute the derivative:

children.html: (r−3)2⋅P+P4=e4r⋅(r−3)+16/′2(r−3)P+(r−3)2P′+4P3P′=4e4r(r−3)+e4r\begin{split} (r-3)^2 \cdot P + P^4 &= e^{4r} \cdot (r-3) + 16 \quad /' \\ 2(r-3)P + (r-3)^2 P' + 4P^3P' &= 4e^{4r}(r-3) + e^{4r} \end{split}(r−3)2⋅P+P42(r−3)P+(r−3)2P′+4P3P′​=e4r⋅(r−3)+16/′=4e4r(r−3)+e4r​
r=3,r = 3,r=3,
4P(3)3P′(3)=e12.4P(3)^3P'(3) = e^{12}.4P(3)3P′(3)=e12.
r=3r = 3r=3
PPP
P(3)4=16/4  ⟹  P(3)=2.P(3)^4 = 16 \quad / \sqrt[4]{} \implies P(3) = 2.P(3)4=16/4​⟹P(3)=2.
4P(3)3P′(3)=e12  ⟹  32P′(3)=e12  ⟹  P′(3)=e1232.4P(3)^3P'(3) = e^{12} \implies 32 P'(3) = e^{12} \implies P'(3) = \frac{e^{12}}{32}.4P(3)3P′(3)=e12⟹32P′(3)=e12⟹P′(3)=32e12​.

children.value: Finally, we can approximate the change in portfolio’s value using the differential:

children.html: ΔP(3)≈P′(3)⋅dr=e1232⋅0.75=3814.57\Delta P(3) \approx P'(3) \cdot dr = \frac{e^{12}}{32} \cdot 0.75 = 3814.57ΔP(3)≈P′(3)⋅dr=32e12​⋅0.75=3814.57

children.value: Marko, a trader at an investment bank, is developing an algorithm that predicts a stock’s price

children.html: PPP
III

children.value: . Through statistical analysis, Petar models the relationship using the function

children.html: P(I)=(5I+4)I+7.P(I) = (5I+4)^{\sqrt{I+7}}.P(I)=(5I+4)I+7​.

children.value: Marko’s model will be used in live trading only if the error of estimation of the exact change in price stays below

children.html: 5%5\%5%

children.value: of the actual stock price. If the current market index is equal to
, help Marko determine the maximum displacement of the market index that ensures that the error made using his model remains below the given threshold.
If the initial market index is equal to

children.html: I0=2,I_0 = 2,I0​=2,

children.value: then the initial price of the stock is

children.html: P(2)=2744.P(2) = 2744.P(2)=2744.

children.value: Our task is to find by how much can the market index change so that Marko’s function gives accurate values up to

children.html: 5%5\%5%

children.value: of the inital value that is equal to

children.html: P(2)=2744.P(2) = 2744.P(2)=2744.
dIdIdI

children.value: that displacement of the market index, we would need to solve the following inequality:

children.html: ∣P(2+dI)−P(2)∣≤5100⋅P(2)  ⟺  ∣(14+5dI)9+dI−2744∣≤137.2\begin{split} \lvert P(2+dI) - P(2) \rvert &\leq \frac{5}{100} \cdot P(2) \\ \iff \lvert (14+5dI)^{\sqrt{9+dI}} - 2744 \rvert &\leq 137.2 \end{split}∣P(2+dI)−P(2)∣⟺∣(14+5dI)9+dI​−2744∣​≤1005​⋅P(2)≤137.2​

children.value: Of course, this inequality is far to complicated for us to solve, so we need to change our approach.
the differential approximates the exact change

children.html: ΔP(2)≈P′(2)⋅dI.\Delta P(2) \approx P'(2) \cdot dI.ΔP(2)≈P′(2)⋅dI.

children.value: Therefore, we have the following approximation

children.html: ∣P′(2)⋅dI∣≈∣ΔP(2)∣≤1100P(2).  ⟺  ∣P′(2)⋅dI∣≤137.2\begin{split} \lvert P'(2) \cdot dI \rvert \approx \lvert \Delta P(2) \rvert &\leq \frac{1}{100} P(2). \\ \iff \lvert P'(2) \cdot dI \rvert &\leq 137.2 \end{split}∣P′(2)⋅dI∣≈∣ΔP(2)∣⟺∣P′(2)⋅dI∣​≤1001​P(2).≤137.2​

children.value: This inequality we know how to solve. First of all, we need to find the derivative

children.html: P′(2).P'(2).P′(2).
P′(I)=P(I)⋅(ln⁡(5I+4)2I+7+5I+75I+4)P'(I) = P(I) \cdot \left(\frac{\ln(5I+4)}{2\sqrt{I+7}} + \frac{5\sqrt{I+7}}{5I+4} \right)P′(I)=P(I)⋅(2I+7​ln(5I+4)​+5I+45I+7​​)
I=2,I = 2,I=2,
P′(2)=2744⋅(ln⁡(14)6+1514).P'(2) = 2744 \cdot \left( \frac{\ln(14)}{6} + \frac{15}{14}\right).P′(2)=2744⋅(6ln(14)​+1415​).

children.value: Now, the problem boils down to a simple inequality

children.html: ∣P′(2)⋅dI∣≤137.2  ⟹  ∣dI∣≤137.2P′(2)=0.033\begin{split} \lvert P'(2) \cdot dI \rvert &\leq 137.2 \\ \implies \lvert dI \rvert &\leq \frac{137.2}{P'(2)} = 0.033 \end{split}∣P′(2)⋅dI∣⟹∣dI∣​≤137.2≤P′(2)137.2​=0.033​

children.value: Therefore, we have estimated that if the market index changes up to

children.html: ±0.033,\pm 0.033,±0.033,

children.value: accuracy of Marko’s model will be withing

children.html: 5%5\%5%

children.value: In order to see if our estimates are accurate or not, let’s compute the exact change in portfolio value given that the market index changes by at most

children.html: ±0.03\pm 0.03±0.03

∣P(2,03)−P(2)∣=126.902<137.2∣P(1.97)−P(2)∣=121.972<137.2\begin{split} \lvert P(2,03)-P(2) \rvert & = 126.902 < 137.2 \\ \lvert P(1.97) - P(2) \rvert & = 121.972 < 137.2 \end{split}∣P(2,03)−P(2)∣∣P(1.97)−P(2)∣​=126.902<137.2=121.972<137.2​

children.value: Therefore, we see that our estimates are accurate, i.e. they ensure that the error made using Marko’s model remain under the given threshold.
